briefOverview: Joseph Smith instructs the Saints on the doctrinal basis and precise record-keeping required for baptism for the dead, linking earthly records with heavenly sealing. He culminates with a sweeping testimony of restored priesthood keys and an exhortation to present an acceptable book of the dead in the temple.
summary: Smith outlines a system of local and general recorders, with multiple witnesses and certified copies, so that earthly records of proxy baptisms will be acknowledged in heaven. He grounds this in Revelation 20:12 and the promise that what is bound or recorded on earth is bound or recorded in heaven, emphasizing the priesthood keys that authorize such acts. He explains the symbolism of baptism and the font as likenesses of death and resurrection, and cites Paul’s mention of baptism for the dead (1 Corinthians 15:29) and Malachi’s prophecy of Elijah turning hearts between fathers and children as a welding link across dispensations. He insists that the salvation of the living and the dead is mutually interdependent. He then rehearses voices and angelic ministrations connected with the Restoration, urging courage and rejoicing. He calls the church to present, in the finished temple, a book containing accurate records of the dead as an offering in righteousness and closes the epistle.
externalContext: This epistle dates to the early 1840s in Nauvoo, Illinois, when temple construction was underway and Latter-day Saints had recently begun performing baptisms for the dead. At first, proxy baptisms were performed in the Mississippi River until a font in the Nauvoo Temple basement was dedicated. Joseph Smith was facing legal pressures and periods of hiding, which shaped the epistolary format of instructions to the church. Early Latter-day Saint administration included wards and appointed recorders responsible for meticulous ecclesiastical records.
externalReferences: The chapter explicitly cites Revelation 20:12 to justify keeping precise earthly records that correspond with heavenly books of life. It appeals to Matthew 16:18–19 on binding and loosing as the basis for priesthood keys and sealing authority, and to 1 Corinthians 15:29 as evidence that early Christians knew of baptism for the dead, alongside 1 Corinthians 15:46–48 for natural/spiritual correspondences. It interprets Malachi 4:5–6 (and echoes Malachi 3:2–3 near the close) as predicting Elijah’s return to create a generational welding link. The celebratory language also alludes to Isaiah 52:7 (“How beautiful upon the mountains…”) and resonates with Job 38:7 (“morning stars… sons of God”) when calling all creation to rejoice.
practicalQuestions: How carefully do I verify, witness, and preserve sacred records so they are “worthy of all acceptation”?
What am I doing to identify my ancestors and prepare names for proxy ordinances as part of turning hearts across generations?
How does believing in binding power affect the way I approach covenants, ordinances, and accountability?
In what ways can my temple worship reflect the likeness of death and resurrection that baptism symbolizes?
How can I combine rejoicing in restoration blessings with steady, detailed diligence in the work for the dead?
uncertainAreas: The exact historical sequencing of the angelic visitations listed is asserted rather than detailed; the identification of Raphael is not explained. The application of Malachi 4:5–6 explicitly to baptism for the dead is interpretive. The extent to which the “book” presented in the temple is literal versus symbolic may be read in more than one way.
